    B --> C[Close-Range Defense]

    style A fill:#4CAF50,color:#fff
  • Prerequisite games: None — this is foundational
  • Follow-on games: Evade the Punch, Close-Range Defense
  • Related concepts: Defensive Solutions in Striking (Evasion)

System Evolution Notice

This game may be refined as defensive skill development patterns emerge.

docs.title: Wall Stand-Up & Re-Pin Loop
docs.text:
Game Identity

  • Problem: Repeated stand-up and control cycles near the wall
  • Environment: Wall / Ground (hybrid)
  • Stage: Counter ↔ Stabilize

This game teaches the cyclical nature of wall fighting. Positions near the wall rarely resolve in a single action — athletes cycle between ground control, stand-up attempts, and re-pinning.

docs.title: Goal
docs.text:
This is an asymmetric game with cyclical dynamics.

Role Objective Defender Stand using the wall, turn to face, and disengage or reverse Attacker Prevent disengagement, re-pin, or flatten to re-establish control

The objective is loop management — understanding how positions cycle.

docs.title: Entry Condition
docs.text:
• Defender starts in a compromised ground position near wall (seated, turtle, or elbow-post)
  • Attacker has partial control but not full pin
  • Wall is accessible to defender
  • Reset if defender fully disengages or attacker establishes TKO pin

docs.title: Invariants
docs.text:
1. Wall access is always available to defender
  2. Disengagement ends the exchange — defender wins
  3. Control must be re-earned after each stand-up attempt

docs.title: Key Logic: The Stand-Up Cycle
docs.text:
flowchart TD
    A[Defender initiates stand-up] --> B[Attacker follows]
    B --> C{Position resolves?}
    C -->|Defender escapes| D[Defender wins]
    C -->|Attacker re-pins| E[Loop repeats]
    E --> A

    style D fill:#4CAF50,color:#fff
    style E fill:#FF9800,color:#fff

docs.title: Wall as Double-Edged Constraint
docs.text:
The wall helps both athletes:

Athlete How Wall Helps Defender Provides structure to build base and stand Attacker Limits escape routes and provides pinning surface

The athlete who uses the wall more intelligently gains advantage.

docs.title: Turning Before Disengaging
docs.text:
Critical Defensive Principle

Turn to face before attempting to disengage.

Approach Result Disengage while facing away Back exposed, re-clinch easy, striker access dangerous Turn first, then disengage Defensive posture established, disengage viable, counter available

docs.title: Win Conditions
docs.text:
Role Win Conditions Defender Standing + disengaging (creating space while facing attacker) OR reversing (achieving dominant position) Attacker Re-pin (re-establishing wall control) OR flattening (returning to ground control) OR TKO pin

Multiple win conditions reflect the cyclical nature of the position.

docs.title: Levels
docs.text:
Level 1 — Stand-UpLevel 2 — Stand-Up + DisengageLevel 3 — Stand-Up + ReversalLevel 4 — Full MMA Expression
  • Focus on rising from compromised position using wall
  • No strikes
  • Success = standing with wall behind
  • Must turn to face and create space
  • Attacker follows aggressively
  • Success = facing attacker with space to reset
  • Defender attempts to achieve dominant position
  • Reversal = defender now has attacker pinned
  • Highest difficulty — requires reading attacker's balance
  • Light strikes permitted for both players
  • Attacker uses strikes to discourage stand-up and re-establish control
  • Defender uses strikes to create stand-up opportunities
  • Ground-and-pound threat makes positional cycling more urgent
  • Focus: Wall stand-up dynamics under realistic striking pressure
  • See: Full MMA Expression

docs.title: Advanced Expressions (Coach Context)
docs.text:
For defenders:

  • Stand-up timing becomes precise — act during attacker adjustment
  • Wall usage becomes efficient — minimal effort, maximum effect
  • Turn-and-face becomes automatic
  • Reversal opportunities emerge from attacker over-commitment

For attackers:

  • Following becomes controlled, not desperate
  • Re-pinning becomes smooth — continuous control through transitions
  • Flattening becomes available when stand-up is anticipated
  • TKO pin access emerges from successful re-pins

Advanced Insight

At advanced levels, athletes recognize which part of the loop favors them and work to stay there.

docs.title: System Position
docs.text:
flowchart LR
    A[Wall → Ground] --> B[Stand-Up Loop]
    B -.-> C[TKO Pin emerges]
    B --> D[Future ground games]

    style B fill:#9C27B0,color:#fff

This game teaches that positions are not static — they cycle.

System Evolution Notice

Loop dynamics may evolve as patterns are observed.

docs.title: Sustained Offense
docs.text:
Game Identity

  • Problem: Maintaining offensive rhythm through opponent's defensive attempts
  • Environment: Open Space
  • Stage: Access → Stabilize (Offensive Dominance)

This is an intermediate offensive game that teaches maintaining attack through resistance. The attacker learns to continue striking when the opponent attempts to counter, escape, or nullify — without losing rhythm or resetting.

docs.title: Goal
docs.text:
This is an asymmetric game with distinct roles.

Role Objective Attacker Maintain continuous striking offense through defensive attempts Defender Interrupt attacker's rhythm through counters, movement, or clinch

The objective is sustained pressure, not single-shot landing.

docs.title: Entry Condition
docs.text:
• Attacker starts with initiative (slight forward pressure)
  • Defender in defensive posture
  • Attacker attempts to maintain continuous offense
  • Reset when attacker's rhythm is fully broken or defender escapes

docs.title: Invariants
docs.text:
1. Attacker must continue offense — single shots followed by reset don't count
  2. Defender actively tries to interrupt — not passive defense
  3. Brief defensive moments by attacker are allowed if rhythm continues
  4. Full reset by attacker = defender succeeds

docs.title: Attacker
docs.text:
• Chain strikes into combinations
  • When defender counters, evade/absorb seamlessly and continue
  • When defender moves, follow and continue
  • When defender clinches, disengage and continue

docs.title: Defender
docs.text:
• Counter after defensive moments
  • Move to create space
  • Clinch to break rhythm
  • Shoot to threaten takedown

Key Internal Questions — Attacker

  • "Can I continue after this defensive moment?"
  • "Am I following their movement or chasing?"
  • "Is my rhythm broken or just paused?"

docs.title: Key Logic: Seamless Defense Within Offense
docs.text:
The Core Skill

The attacker's defensive awareness doesn't interrupt their offense:

Defender Attempts Attacker Response Counter strike Slip/absorb, continue Move away Follow, continue Clinch Disengage, continue Shoot Sprawl, continue

The key: continue without full reset.

This is different from basic offense (landing targets) — it's about maintaining pressure through resistance.

docs.title: Win Conditions
docs.text:
Role Win Condition Attacker Sustained offensive sequence (e.g., 10+ seconds of continuous pressure) Defender Force attacker to fully reset and re-engage

On attacker win: Roles switch. On defender win: Reset, same roles, defender continues trying to break rhythm.

docs.title: Levels
docs.text:
Level 1 — Counter Strikes OnlyLevel 2 — Add MovementLevel 3 — Add ClinchLevel 4 — Full MMA Expression
  • Defender can only counter-strike
  • Attacker maintains rhythm through counters
  • Focus: Seamless defense within offense
  • Defender can counter AND move to escape
  • Attacker must follow while maintaining rhythm
  • Focus: Pressure without chasing
  • Defender can counter, move, AND clinch
  • Attacker must disengage and continue
  • Focus: Managing clinch attempts
  • Defender can counter, move, clinch, OR shoot
  • Attacker must maintain rhythm through all threats
  • Focus: Sustained offense under MMA reality
  • See: Full MMA Expression

docs.title: Safety
docs.text:
• Contact limits: Light to moderate
  • Stop conditions: Attacker chasing recklessly, excessive force
  • Coach intervention: Reset if exchanges become chaotic

docs.title: System Position
docs.text:
flowchart LR
    A[Land the Target] --> B[Sustained Offense]
    B --> C[Pressure to Takedown]
    B --> D[Pressure to Wall]

    style B fill:#FF5722,color:#fff
  • Prerequisite games: Land the Target
  • Follow-on games: Pressure to Takedown, Pressure to Wall
  • Related concepts: Three Zones, Confidence Rating

System Evolution Notice

This game may be refined as sustained offense patterns emerge.

docs.title: Takedown Defense
docs.text:
Game Identity

  • Problem: Defending takedown attempts in open space
  • Environment: Open Space
  • Stage: Counter (Defensive Wrestling)

This is a defensive wrestling game focused on stopping takedown attempts. The defender learns to recognize shots, sprawl effectively, and recover position after defending.

docs.title: Goal
docs.text:
This is an asymmetric game with distinct roles.

Role Objective Attacker Complete a takedown to ground control Defender Deny the takedown and return to standing neutral

The objective is takedown denial, not escape from ground.

docs.title: Entry Condition
docs.text:
• Both players start standing at clinch range
  • Attacker attempts takedowns (shots, trips, throws)
  • Defender uses defensive wrestling
  • Reset when takedown is completed OR defender fully disengages

docs.title: Invariants
docs.text:
1. Attacker initiates takedowns — no waiting for defender to attack
  2. Defender cannot strike at Level 1 — wrestling defense only
  3. If taken down, game ends — this is not a ground escape game
  4. DNS is allowed for defender as defensive tool

docs.title: Attacker
docs.text:
• Shoot single legs, double legs
  • Set up takedowns with level changes
  • Chain attempts when first is defended
  • Follow through on successful entries

docs.title: Defender
docs.text:
• Recognize shot initiation early
  • Sprawl effectively
  • Use whizzer, crossface, and frames
  • Disengage cleanly after defending

Key Internal Questions — Defender

  • "Am I reading the level change early enough?"
  • "Is my sprawl stopping their drive?"
  • "Can I disengage or do I need to fight the position?"

docs.title: Key Logic: Sprawl and Recover
docs.text:
The Core Skill

Takedown defense follows a pattern:

  1. Read — Recognize the level change or shot
  2. Sprawl — Hips back, weight down on attacker
  3. Fight — Whizzer, crossface, deny completion
  4. Recover — Disengage to neutral standing

The goal is not to win position — it's to deny the takedown and reset.

docs.title: Win Conditions
docs.text:
Role Win Condition Attacker Complete takedown with control on ground Defender Deny takedown and disengage to standing

On defender win: Roles switch — defender becomes attacker. On attacker win: Reset, same roles.

docs.title: Levels
docs.text:
Level 1 — No StrikesLevel 2 — Attacker Sets UpLevel 3 — Add DNSLevel 4 — Full MMA Expression
  • Pure wrestling defense
  • No strikes from either player
  • Focus: Sprawl mechanics and recovery
  • Attacker can use feints and level changes to set up shots
  • Defender must read real vs. fake
  • Focus: Shot recognition
  • Defender can threaten guillotine/front headlock
  • Punishes poor head position
  • Focus: DNS as defensive weapon
  • Defender can strike AND sprawl
  • Attacker must shoot through strike threat
  • Focus: Takedown defense under MMA pressure
  • See: Full MMA Expression

docs.title: Safety
docs.text:
• Contact limits: Controlled shots, no slamming
  • Stop conditions: Uncontrolled takedowns, neck cranks
  • Coach intervention: Reset if positions stall

docs.title: System Position
docs.text:
flowchart LR
    A[Winning the Circle] --> B[Takedown Defense]
    C[Pressure to Takedown] -.->|opposite| B

    style B fill:#4CAF50,color:#fff
  • Prerequisite games: Winning the Circle (recommended)
  • Follow-on games: Open Space Takedown (combined perspective)
  • Related concepts: DNS

System Evolution Notice

This game may be refined as defensive wrestling patterns emerge.

docs.title: Tight Block
docs.text:
Game Identity

  • Problem: Learning to absorb strikes using a tight guard/shell
  • Environment: Open Space
  • Stage: Access (Defensive Skill Isolation)

This is a beginner skill isolation game that teaches the blocking defensive solution. The defender can ONLY block using a tight shell, forcing them to develop this foundational skill.

docs.title: Goal
docs.text:
This is an asymmetric game with distinct roles.

Role Objective Attacker Land punches (straights and hooks) to defender's head or body Defender Block punches using tight guard (shell up, elbows in, hands protecting head)

The objective is skill development, not competition.

docs.title: Entry Condition
docs.text:
• Both players start in neutral standing position
  • Close quarters distance (striking range)
  • Roles are assigned; defender earns role switch through successful defense
  • Reset to neutral after each exchange

docs.title: Invariants
docs.text:
1. Attacker throws straights and/or hooks (scaled to level)
  2. Defender can ONLY block — no parrying, dodging, or backing up continuously
  3. Attacker allows reset between strikes (no continuous pressure at Level 1)

docs.title: Attacker
docs.text:
• Land clean punches to head or body
  • Vary targets and punch types to challenge defender
  • Scale difficulty based on defender success

docs.title: Defender
docs.text:
• Maintain tight guard position (hands to face, elbows protecting body)
  • Absorb strikes on arms and gloves, not on exposed targets
  • Reset to good position after each defensive sequence

Key Internal Questions

  • "Is my guard tight enough to protect my head?"
  • "Are my elbows covering my body?"
  • "Am I absorbing on my arms or getting hit clean?"

docs.title: Key Logic: Why Isolate Blocking?
docs.text:
Skill Isolation

Blocking is the most fundamental defensive solution. By constraining the defender to blocking only:

  • Develops the habit of shelling up under pressure
  • Learns to absorb on arms/gloves rather than exposed targets
  • Builds composure when taking fire

docs.title: Blocking Mechanics
docs.text:
• Tight guard = Hands to face, elbows to body, chin tucked
  • Works for both straights and hooks (unlike parrying or slipping)
  • Trade-off: Maximum protection, but no counter opportunity and hands are occupied

docs.title: Why Blocking Differs from Parrying
docs.text: Aspect Blocking Parrying Strike types Straights AND hooks Straights only Movement Static/absorbing Active/redirecting Energy Absorbs impact Deflects impact Counter setup Minimal Creates opening

docs.title: Win Conditions
docs.text:
Role Win Condition Defender Absorb the attack sequence on guard (no clean contact to exposed targets) Attacker Land a clean strike to head or body (not absorbed on arms/gloves)

On defender win: Roles switch — defender becomes attacker.

On attacker win: Reset to neutral, same roles, attacker continues.

The defender must earn the offensive position by proving they can block effectively.

The Strategic Insight

You don't need to perfectly block every strike. You can take some contact while reading the attacker's rhythm and adjusting your guard. When you successfully absorb a complete attack sequence without getting hit clean — that's the skill demonstration.

At higher levels (combinations), this means surviving the entire combination on your guard. One clean defensive success earns the role switch.

Duration: Play until natural stopping point or time limit. Role switches keep both players engaged.

docs.title: Levels
docs.text:
Level 1 — Single Punches, Straights OnlyLevel 2 — Add HooksLevel 3 — Variable TempoLevel 4 — CombinationsLevel 5 — Full MMA Expression
  • One straight punch at a time
  • 1-second reset between punches
  • Defender: tight block only
  • Attacker can throw straights OR hooks
  • Defender adjusts guard for different angles
  • Focus: Covering multiple attack lines
  • Attacker varies timing between strikes
  • No fixed reset requirement
  • Defender must stay ready
  • Attacker throws 2-4 punch combinations
  • Mix of straights and hooks
  • Defender absorbs full combinations on guard
  • Focus: Maintaining structure through sustained pressure
  • Attacker throws combinations AND can shoot or establish clinch
  • Attacker wins by: landing clean strike OR establishing meaningful clinch/connection
  • Defender must block effectively AND deny grappling entry
  • Focus: Blocking while remaining aware of all threats
  • This is the MMA reality: shelling up without posture creates takedown opportunities

docs.title: Safety
docs.text:
• Contact limits: Light to moderate — punches should be felt but not damaging
  • Stop conditions: Loss of composure, guard breakdown, excessive force
  • Coach intervention: Reset if defender starts moving/dodging instead of blocking

docs.text:

    C[Parry the Straight] --> B
    D[Slip the Straight] --> B

    style A fill:#4CAF50,color:#fff

  • Follow-on games: Close-Range Defense

This game may be refined as defensive skill development patterns emerge.

docs.title: Touch and Don't Get Touched
docs.text:
Game Identity

  • Problem: Range awareness, timing, and first-contact literacy
  • Environment: Open Space (no boundaries)
  • Stage: Access (Pre-Space, Pre-Pressure)

This is the foundational engagement game in the system. It exists before space control, pressure, or clinch logic.

docs.title: Goal
docs.text:
This is a mirrored game.

Each player aims to:

  • Touch the opponent
  • Avoid being touched
  • Deny or negate the opponent's ability to respond

The objective is initiative management, not damage accumulation.

docs.title: Entry Condition
docs.text:
• Both players start in open space
  • No wall, boundary, or circling requirement
  • Neutral stance at a comfortable distance
  • Reset to neutral distance after each resolved exchange

docs.title: Invariants
docs.text:
1. No sustained pressure
  2. No forward crashing or collisions
  3. No takedowns unless explicitly permitted by level
  4. Each exchange resolves quickly and resets
  5. The game remains exploratory, not competitive

docs.title: Both Players
docs.text:
• Read distance honestly
  • Coordinate eyes, feet, and hands
  • Time entry and exit cleanly
  • Maintain composure after contact
  • Recover initiative immediately when touched

Key Internal Questions

  • "Am I actually in range?"
  • "Can I enter without being hit back?"
  • "If I get touched, can I respond immediately?"

docs.title: Legal Actions
docs.text:
• Light touches to head or torso
  • Punches and kicks allowed
  • Single strike or maximum two-strike sequence
  • Probing jabs encouraged
  • No flurries
  • No prolonged clinch unless allowed by level

All contact is touch/light only.

docs.title: Counter-Touch Logic (Critical)
docs.text:
This is the core mechanic of the game

If a player is touched:

  • They are allowed one immediate opportunity to touch back
  • The counter-touch must occur within the same exchange window
  • No chasing once the moment has passed

Exchange outcomes:

Outcome Result Clean touch without response Advantage Touch followed by immediate counter-touch Neutral (1-for-1) Getting touched without response Lost exchange

This logic rewards:

  • Composure under contact
  • Counter-striking awareness
  • Recovery of initiative

docs.title: Win Conditions
docs.text:
This game is diagnostic, not score-driven.

Success is evaluated by:

  • Frequency of clean touches
  • Quality of counter-touches
  • Reduced panic after contact
  • Improved range accuracy and timing

docs.title: Levels
docs.text:
Level 1 — Hands OnlyLevel 2 — Hands + KicksLevel 3 — Counter EmphasisLevel 4 — Hand Control as DenialLevel 5 — Clinch as DenialLevel 6 — Full MMA Expression
  • Punches only
  • Focus on jab range and hand timing
  • Kicks introduced
  • Teaches layered range awareness
  • Counter-touch strongly emphasized
  • Poor entries are punished immediately
  • Hand fighting and hand control allowed
  • Brief two-on-one control permitted
  • Goal remains: touch and deny response
  • Clinch entry allowed only as an immediate response to touch
  • Hands-connected clinch, level change, or leg connection counts as denial
  • Once denial is achieved, the exchange ends
  • Takedown entry allowed as denial response (level change, shot)
  • If clinch is established, brief continuation permitted
  • Full MMA denial options: counter-touch, clinch, or takedown threat
  • Focus: Complete denial toolkit under MMA reality
  • See: Full MMA Expression

docs.title: Advanced Expressions (Coach Context)
docs.text:
As athletes advance, the meaning of "don't get touched" expands.

At higher skill levels, denying a response may include:

  • Controlling or interfering with the opponent's hands
  • Entering into clinch or level change
  • Removing the opponent's ability to strike at all

These are treated as solutions, not objectives.

Core Problem Never Changes

  • Initiate contact
  • Deny effective response

Clinching is not rewarded by default. It is rewarded only insofar as it prevents a counter-touch.

docs.title: Safety
docs.text:
• Touch contact only
  • No forward collisions
  • No chasing after missed strikes
  • Coach may pause play if structure degrades

docs.title: System Position
docs.text:
flowchart LR
    A[Touch Game] --> B[Winning the Circle]
    B --> C[All downstream games]

    style A fill:#4CAF50,color:#fff

This game precedes:

  • Winning the Circle
  • All pressure-based striking games
  • All clinch recognition games

It builds the perceptual and timing foundation for the entire system.

System Evolution Notice

This game reflects the current best understanding of engagement literacy. It may be revised as new insights or safety considerations emerge.

docs.title: Wall Control — Establish the Pin
docs.text:
Game Identity

  • Problem: Immobilizing opponent against the wall
  • Environment: Wall
  • Stage: Stabilize

This game teaches vertical control. The wall becomes the dominant constraint — it limits the defender's options and creates opportunities for organized control.

docs.title: Goal
docs.text:
This is an asymmetric game focused on control establishment.

Role Objective Attacker Establish a functional wall pin (hips and shoulders controlled, rotation denied) Defender Prevent pin establishment or disengage before being flattened

The objective is stabilization, not damage or advancement.

docs.title: Entry Condition
docs.text:
• Start from clinch with defender positioned between attacker and wall
  • Distance: 1–2 feet from wall
  • Attacker has initial connection but not yet established control
  • Reset if defender creates significant space or fully disengages

docs.title: Invariants
docs.text:
1. Wall is dominant constraint — all control is relative to it
  2. No immediate takedowns — stabilize before advancing
  3. Defender actively resists — no passive drilling

docs.title: Key Logic: What Constitutes a Pin?
docs.text:
A pin is NOT just pressing someone against the wall

A functional wall pin exists when:

  • [x] Defender's shoulders are substantially flat to wall
  • [x] Defender's hips are controlled or compromised
  • [x] Defender cannot rotate freely
  • [x] Attacker maintains structure and balance

It requires organized control.

docs.title: The Rotation Problem
docs.text:
The primary escape mechanism is shoulder rotation. If the defender can turn their shoulders, they can:

  • Create frames
  • Generate hip movement
  • Threaten reversals
  • Access escape angles

The attacker's primary task is denying rotation while maintaining their own balance.

docs.title: DNS as Defensive Pressure
docs.text:
Defensive Neck Submissions

DNS (guillotine threats, front headlock entries) are permitted for the defender. This punishes:

  • Poor posture from the attacker
  • Over-commitment to control
  • Head position errors

DNS keeps the attacker honest without changing the game's focus.

docs.title: Win Conditions
docs.text:
Role Win Condition Attacker Holding functional pin for 5 seconds Defender Disengaging (creating space) or reversing position

5-second hold requirement ensures the pin is stable, not momentary.

docs.title: Levels
docs.text:
Level 1 — Establish PinLevel 2 — Deny RotationLevel 3 — Threaten TKO Pin AccessLevel 4 — Full MMA Expression
  • Focus on achieving flat shoulders and hip control
  • No strikes
  • Defender resists but does not counter-attack
  • Defender actively works rotation escapes
  • Attacker must adjust and re-pin
  • Light strikes permitted
  • Attacker may briefly release one control point to simulate strike access
  • Pin must be re-established after strike threat
  • Introduces trade-off between control and damage
  • Light strikes permitted for both players
  • Attacker can use strikes to soften resistance and maintain pin
  • Defender can use strikes to create escape opportunities
  • Knee strikes available for attacker from control
  • Focus: Wall control under realistic striking pressure
  • See: Full MMA Expression

docs.title: Advanced Expressions (Coach Context)
docs.text:
For attackers:

  • Pin becomes a platform, not an endpoint
  • Control becomes dynamic — adjustments without losing position
  • Strike threats emerge from stable control
  • TKO pin access becomes available at Level 3+

For defenders:

  • Early rotation becomes instinctive
  • Frames become structural rather than desperate
  • DNS threats become genuine tactical options
  • Escape timing improves — act before consolidation

docs.title: System Position
docs.text:
flowchart TD
    A[Boundary Trigger] --> B[Wall Control]
    B --> C[Wall Escape]
    B --> D[Wall → Ground]

    style B fill:#2196F3,color:#fff

This is the first true grappling control game in the system.

System Evolution Notice

Pin definitions may evolve as control models refine.

docs.title: Wall Defensive Submission
docs.text:
Game Identity

  • Problem: Using submissions to deter or reverse wall control
  • Environment: Wall
  • Stage: Counter (Defensive Grappling)

This is a defensive grappling game where the pinned player uses submission threats to deter control and create escape opportunities. Submissions from defensive wall position serve as both threat and escape tool.

docs.title: Goal
docs.text:
This is an asymmetric game with distinct roles.

Role Objective Defender (Pinned) Threaten or complete submission from defensive position Controller Maintain wall control while avoiding submission danger

The objective is submission as defensive weapon — making control dangerous.

docs.title: Entry Condition
docs.text:
• Defender is pinned against wall
  • Controller has established wall control
  • Defender works submission threats
  • Reset when submission achieved, defended, OR controller disengages

docs.title: Invariants
docs.text:
1. Defender must threaten submissions — not just escape
  2. Controller maintains intent to control — not just defending
  3. Submissions must be available from position (not fantasy techniques)
  4. Wall position remains the environment

docs.title: Defender (Pinned)
docs.text:
• Identify submission opportunities from position
  • Threaten guilotine, front headlock, Kimura, etc.
  • Use submission threat to create escape
  • Finish if controller gives the opening

docs.title: Controller (Offensive)
docs.text:
• Maintain position while protecting neck/arms
  • Recognize submission setups
  • Choose: disengage or defend in place
  • Keep head position safe

Key Internal Questions — Defender

  • "What submission is available from here?"
  • "Is their head position vulnerable?"
  • "Can I use this threat to escape even if I don't finish?"

docs.title: Key Logic: Submissions as Deterrent
docs.text:
The Core Skill

Defensive wall submissions serve multiple purposes:

Purpose How It Works Deterrent Makes controller cautious, loosens control Reversal setup Threat creates space to escape Actual finish If controller doesn't respect, finish

Available submissions from wall defense:

  • Guillotine — Controller's head is low
  • Front headlock/DNS — Controller shoots or ducks
  • Kimura — Controller's arm is exposed
  • Standing arm triangle — Rare but possible

The skill is recognizing when submission is available and using it appropriately.

docs.title: Win Conditions
docs.text:
Role Win Condition Defender Complete submission OR use threat to escape Controller Maintain control while defending submissions for set duration

On defender win: Roles switch. On controller win: Reset, same roles.

docs.title: Levels
docs.text:
Level 1 — Guillotine OnlyLevel 2 — Add Arm AttacksLevel 3 — Submission to EscapeLevel 4 — Full MMA Expression
  • Defender can only threaten guillotine
  • Focus: Recognizing head position vulnerability
  • Defender can threaten guillotine and Kimura
  • Multiple submission threats
  • Focus: Reading which submission is available
  • Defender uses threats to create escape
  • Score for escape OR submission
  • Focus: Submission as escape tool
  • Controller can strike during wall control
  • Defender must time submissions around strikes
  • Focus: Defensive submissions under MMA pressure
  • See: Full MMA Expression

docs.title: Safety
docs.text:
• Contact limits: Controlled submissions, tap early
  • Stop conditions: Cranking submissions, slamming
  • Coach intervention: Reset if stalling without progress

docs.title: System Position
docs.text:
flowchart LR
    A[Wall Control] --> B[Wall Escape]
    A --> C[Wall Defensive Submission]
    C --> D((Submission))

    style C fill:#4CAF50,color:#fff
    style D fill:#D32F2F,color:#fff
  • Prerequisite games: Wall Escape (understand wall defense first)
  • Follow-on games: End state (Submission) if completed
  • Related concepts: DNS, Defensive Solutions

System Evolution Notice

This game may be refined as wall submission patterns emerge.

docs.title: Wall Escape — Anti-Pin
docs.text:
Game Identity

  • Problem: Escaping wall immobilization
  • Environment: Wall
  • Stage: Counter

This is the defensive counterpart to Wall Control. Every offensive layer requires a defensive response.

docs.title: Goal
docs.text:
This is an asymmetric game with inverted priorities.

Role Objective Defender (primary focus) Break pin and return to space or reverse position Attacker Maintain pin and deny escape

The objective is escape or reversal, not survival.

docs.title: Entry Condition
docs.text:
• Start from functional wall pin (attacker has established control)
  • Defender's shoulders are substantially flat to wall
  • Defender's rotation is initially compromised
  • Reset if attacker loses control completely or defender fully disengages

docs.title: Invariants
docs.text:
1. Wall remains dominant constraint
  2. Defender must actively attempt escape — no passive survival
  3. No takedowns yet — focus is on breaking the pin

docs.title: Key Logic: The Escape Sequence
docs.text:
Escapes follow a general pattern:

flowchart LR
    A[Rotate Shoulders] --> B[Create Frames]
    B --> C[Move Hips]
    C --> D[Turn to Face]
    D --> E[Disengage or Reverse]

    style A fill:#4CAF50,color:#fff
    style E fill:#FF5722,color:#fff

Critical Order

Attempting to disengage before rotating typically fails.

docs.title: Early vs Late Escape
docs.text:
Type Description Effort Required Early escape Act before pin consolidates Lower — requires reading Late escape Act after pin is established Higher — exposes to damage

The game teaches athletes to escape early by recognizing consolidation.

docs.title: DNS as Escape Catalyst
docs.text:
When the attacker's head drops or posture breaks:

  • Guillotine threats become available
  • Front headlock entries open up
  • Attacker must choose between maintaining pin and protecting neck

DNS doesn't need to finish

It creates decision pressure that enables escape.

docs.title: Win Conditions
docs.text:
Role Win Condition Defender Escape (creating space and facing attacker) or reversal Attacker Sustained pin (10 seconds)

Longer hold requirement reflects the disadvantaged starting position for defender.

docs.title: Levels
docs.text:
Level 1 — EscapeLevel 2 — Escape + DisengageLevel 3 — Escape + ReverseLevel 4 — Full MMA Expression
  • Focus on breaking pin and creating space
  • No strikes
  • Success = shoulders no longer flat + facing attacker
  • Must create meaningful space after breaking pin
  • Disengage = return to striking range with defensive posture
  • Attacker may follow and attempt re-clinch
  • Defender attempts to achieve dominant position
  • Reversal = defender now has attacker against wall
  • Highest difficulty — requires reading attacker's balance
  • Light strikes permitted for both players
  • Attacker can use strikes to maintain pin pressure
  • Defender can use strikes to create escape opportunities
  • Escape becomes more urgent under strike threat
  • Focus: Wall escape under realistic striking pressure
  • See: Full MMA Expression

docs.title: Advanced Expressions (Coach Context)
docs.text:
As athletes develop, escape becomes proactive rather than reactive:

For defenders:

  • Rotation begins before pin is fully established
  • Frames are pre-positioned, not created under pressure
  • DNS threats become tactical rather than desperate
  • Reversals emerge from attacker over-commitment

For attackers:

  • Adjustment becomes continuous, not reactive
  • Pin maintenance becomes dynamic
  • Respect for DNS becomes structural

docs.title: System Position
docs.text:
flowchart LR
    A[Wall Control] --> B[Wall Escape]

    style B fill:#9C27B0,color:#fff

This game maintains defensive symmetry in the system.

System Evolution Notice

Escape strategies may be refined with experience.

docs.title: Wall Grinding
docs.text:
Game Identity

  • Problem: Dealing damage from wall control position
  • Environment: Wall
  • Stage: Exploit (Wall Damage)

This is an offensive wall game focused on dealing damage from wall position. Unlike Wall to Ground, the goal is NOT to transition — it's to damage the opponent while maintaining wall control.

docs.title: Goal
docs.text:
This is an asymmetric game with distinct roles.

Role Objective Attacker Maintain wall control AND deal significant damage Defender Escape wall OR nullify damage output

The objective is damage from wall, not transition.

docs.title: Entry Condition
docs.text:
• Start from established wall control (attacker has position)
  • Attacker works dirty boxing, knees, grinding
  • Defender attempts escape or damage nullification
  • Reset when defender escapes OR sufficient damage dealt

docs.title: Invariants
docs.text:
1. Attacker must deal damage — just holding doesn't count
  2. Attacker should NOT transition to ground — stay on wall
  3. Defender actively resists — not passive
  4. Position resets if attacker loses wall control completely

docs.title: Attacker
docs.text:
• Maintain wall control (shoulders flat, hips controlled)
  • Find openings for knees, short punches, elbows
  • Manage energy — grinding is work
  • Deny escape while creating damage

docs.title: Defender
docs.text:
• Create frames to block strikes
  • Work rotation escapes
  • Nullify knee opportunities
  • Find reversal or escape opportunities

Key Internal Questions — Attacker

  • "Am I controlling AND damaging, or just one?"
  • "Can I find the opening for a knee?"
  • "Am I maintaining position through their escape attempts?"

docs.title: Key Logic: Control + Damage Balance
docs.text:
The Core Skill

Wall grinding requires balancing two demands:

Priority Risk More control Less damage output More damage Risk losing position

The skill is finding the balance — creating damage opportunities WITHOUT losing control.

This is the "dirty boxing" or "grinding" that characterizes some fighting styles.

docs.title: Win Conditions
docs.text:
Role Win Condition Attacker Sustained damage output from wall (multiple clean strikes) Defender Escape to open space OR nullify damage for extended period

On attacker win: Roles switch. On defender win: Reset, same roles.

docs.title: Levels
docs.text:
Level 1 — Control + StrikesLevel 2 — Add KneesLevel 3 — Defender Strikes BackLevel 4 — Full MMA Expression
  • Attacker maintains control and works short strikes
  • Defender defends and works escape
  • Focus: Finding openings while controlling
  • Attacker can use knees from clinch position
  • More damaging but requires space creation
  • Focus: Knee setups from wall
  • Defender can strike from wall position
  • Attacker must control while managing return fire
  • Focus: Two-way wall exchanges
  • Attacker can choose to transition to ground if advantageous
  • Defender can shoot to escape
  • Focus: Wall fighting under full MMA options
  • See: Full MMA Expression

docs.title: Safety
docs.text:
• Contact limits: Light to moderate — knees especially controlled
  • Stop conditions: Excessive force, loss of composure
  • Coach intervention: Reset if grinding becomes stalling

docs.title: System Position
docs.text:
flowchart LR
    A[Wall Control] --> B[Wall Grinding]
    A --> C[Wall to Ground]
    D[Pressure to Wall] --> B

    style B fill:#FF5722,color:#fff
  • Prerequisite games: Wall Control
  • Follow-on games: N/A (this is an end-state game)
  • Related concepts: TKO Pin (ground equivalent)

System Evolution Notice

This game may be refined as wall damage patterns emerge.

docs.title: Wall Pin → Ground Control
docs.text:
Game Identity

  • Problem: Converting vertical control to horizontal control
  • Environment: Wall → Ground
  • Stage: Stabilize → Exploit

This game teaches the transition from standing wall control to ground control. It is the first game where the ground becomes the dominant environment.

docs.title: Goal
docs.text:
This is an asymmetric game focused on positional transition.

Role Objective Attacker Bring opponent to ground safely and establish hip/shoulder control Defender Scramble during descent, use wall to stand, or exploit sloppy transitions

The objective is controlled transition, not the takedown itself.

docs.title: Entry Condition
docs.text:
• Start from established wall pin (attacker has control)
  • Defender's escape options are limited
  • Attacker initiates transition to ground
  • Reset if defender fully escapes to standing or attacker loses control completely

docs.title: Invariants
docs.text:
Safety-Critical Invariants

  1. No dumping bodyweight — control precedes gravity
  2. Off-balancing precedes descent — takedown is created, not forced
  3. Scrambles are allowed and expected

docs.title: Key Logic: Controlled Descent vs Dumping
docs.text:
Type Characteristics Outcome Controlled descent Connection maintained, base compromised first, attacker lands in position Attacker advantage Dumping Bodyweight or momentum forces descent, control lost Scramble favors defender

The game explicitly rewards controlled descent and punishes dumping through scramble outcomes.

docs.title: The Scramble Window
docs.text:
The transition from wall to ground creates a scramble window — a period where control is contested.

During this window:

  • Both athletes have opportunities
  • Posture and balance determine outcomes
  • DNS threats are most dangerous

Athletes learn to shorten the scramble window (attackers) or exploit it (defenders).

docs.title: Ground Control Criteria
docs.text:
Ground control is established when:

  • [x] Attacker controls defender's hips and shoulders
  • [x] Defender cannot easily stand or reverse
  • [x] Position is stable for 2–3 seconds

Lower Threshold than TKO Pin

This represents control, not dominance.

docs.title: Win Conditions
docs.text: Role Win Condition Attacker Controlled hip and shoulder control on ground (2–3 seconds) Defender Scramble (return to neutral), stand-up (using wall), or reversal

docs.title: Levels
docs.text:
Level 1 — Controlled DescentLevel 2 — Deny ScrambleLevel 3 — Establish TKO Pin ThreatLevel 4 — Full MMA Expression
  • Focus on bringing opponent to ground safely
  • No strikes
  • Success = descent with maintained connection
  • Defender actively scrambles during descent
  • Attacker must follow and establish control
  • Success = control despite scramble attempt
  • After ground control, attacker works toward TKO pin access
  • Strike threats become available
  • Introduces the exploitation layer
  • Light strikes permitted throughout transition
  • Attacker can use strikes to set up takedown and maintain control
  • Defender can use strikes during scramble window
  • Focus: Wall-to-ground transition under realistic striking pressure
  • See: Full MMA Expression

docs.title: Advanced Expressions (Coach Context)
docs.text:
For attackers:

  • Descent timing becomes intuitive
  • Scramble anticipation improves
  • Control on ground emerges immediately from transition
  • TKO pin access becomes available directly from descent

For defenders:

  • Scramble timing becomes precise
  • Wall-assisted recovery becomes instinctive
  • DNS threats become tactical rather than desperate
  • Early posting prevents uncontrolled descent entirely

docs.title: System Position
docs.text:
flowchart TD
    A[Wall Control] --> B[Wall → Ground]
    B --> C[Stand-Up Loop]
    B -.-> D[TKO Pin emerges]

    style B fill:#2196F3,color:#fff
    style D fill:#FF5722,color:#fff

This is the first environment transition game in the system.

System Evolution Notice

Descent mechanics may evolve for safety or realism.

docs.title: Winning the Circle
docs.text:
Game Identity

  • Problem: Space domination and engagement denial
  • Environment: Open Space
  • Stage: Access

This is the primary space-control game in the system. It teaches athletes to manage distance through movement and pressure rather than through blocking or absorbing strikes.

docs.title: Goal
docs.text:
This is an asymmetric game with distinct roles.

Role Objective Outside Player (Attacker) Apply pressure to control space and limit escape routes Inside Player (Defender) Maintain access to open space and avoid being crowded

The objective is spatial control, not damage accumulation.

docs.title: Entry Condition
docs.text:
• Both players start in open space
  • A visible or imagined circular boundary exists (training ring, tape, cones)
  • Roles are assigned and may switch between rounds
  • Reset to neutral distance after each boundary violation

docs.title: Invariants
docs.text:
1. No clinching
  2. No takedowns
  3. Movement is continuous — static exchanges reset

docs.title: Outside Player (Attacker)
docs.text:
• Apply intelligent forward pressure
  • Use footwork, feints, and probing strikes
  • Corral opponent toward boundary
  • Cut off lateral escape routes

docs.title: Inside Player (Defender)
docs.text:
• Maintain space through movement
  • Avoid being crowded or flattened against boundary
  • Minimize need for physical blocking by positional accuracy
  • Recognize when space is shrinking

Key Internal Questions

  • "Am I controlling the center or being pushed to the edge?"
  • "Can I escape laterally, or are my routes being cut?"
  • "Is my pressure creating reactions, or am I just chasing?"

docs.title: Legal Actions
docs.text:
• Strikes: Light punches and kicks allowed
  • Submissions: None
  • Wrestling: None

No flurries (max 2–3 strike sequences). Strikes are informational — they measure distance and create reactions, not damage.

docs.title: Key Logic: Pressure vs Chasing
docs.text:
Critical Distinction

Effective pressure limits options. Chasing follows the opponent.

Signs of chasing:

  • Lunging forward without cutting angles
  • Reacting to movement instead of anticipating it
  • Losing balance or posture during pursuit

Signs of pressure:

  • Opponent's movement becomes predictable
  • Escape routes visibly shrink
  • Attacker maintains composure and structure

The game rewards intelligent pressure and punishes mindless aggression.

docs.title: Win Conditions
docs.text:
Role Win Condition Attacker Defender steps out of the circle Defender Time expires without boundary violation

Typical round length: 60–90 seconds.

docs.title: Levels
docs.text:
Level 1 — Movement OnlyLevel 2 — Add Light StrikesLevel 3 — Feints and Stance ManipulationLevel 4 — Full MMA Expression
  • No strikes
  • Pure footwork and spatial awareness
  • Focus on angles, not speed
  • Punches and kicks permitted
  • Strikes used to create movement, not damage
  • Defender learns to move without flinching
  • Feints count as pressure tools
  • Stance switches and level changes permitted
  • Attacker learns to create false reads
  • Moderate strike contact permitted (not just touch)
  • Counter-striking fully allowed
  • Attacker must manage space while respecting counter threat
  • Defender can counter-attack to regain space
  • Focus: Space control under realistic striking pressure
  • See: Full MMA Expression

docs.title: Advanced Expressions (Coach Context)
docs.text:
As athletes develop, the game reveals deeper layers:

For attackers:

  • Pressure becomes rhythmic rather than constant
  • Feints create more movement than real strikes
  • Cutting angles becomes instinctive

For defenders:

  • Movement becomes smaller and more efficient
  • Circling transitions to pivoting
  • Counter-striking opportunities emerge naturally

Advanced Insight

At advanced levels, the boundary becomes less relevant — the athlete has internalized spatial awareness. The game can then transition to open sparring with spatial goals.

docs.title: Safety
docs.text:
• Contact limits: Touch or light strikes only
  • Stop conditions: Any loss of control, chasing collisions, or boundary disputes
  • Coach intervention: Reset if exchanges become static or if pressure degrades into aggression

docs.title: System Position
docs.text:
flowchart LR

    B --> C[Boundary Trigger]

docs.title: The Academic Approach
docs.text:
The games in this system are academic exercises, not competitions. The goal is learning, not winning.

When you play these games, you are studying. You're experimenting, testing hypotheses, gathering feedback, and building understanding. Points, wins, and role switches are measurement tools — they tell you whether you're grasping the concept. They are not trophies to collect.

docs.title: Be Your Own Harshest Critic
docs.text:
This is the fundamental training mindset for the ecological method:

Only claim wins you genuinely earned.

If a game has an honor system (like claiming when you've landed your target), be honest with yourself. Claiming a false win doesn't help you — it actively hurts your development by giving you false feedback.

Ask yourself: - Did I actually accomplish what the game asks? - Would I be confident saying this counted if someone was watching closely? - Am I learning, or am I gaming the system?

If you're not sure whether something counted, it probably didn't. Reset and try again.

docs.title: Games Are Vehicles, Not Destinations
docs.text:
The games exist to create specific learning conditions. They constrain the environment so you can focus on particular skills. The game itself is not the point — the skill development is.

Wrong Mindset Right Mindset "I need to win this game" "I need to understand this skill" "I scored more points" "I successfully applied the concept" "I beat my partner" "I learned something about how this works"

Your training partner is not your opponent. They're your collaborator in creating the conditions for both of you to learn.

docs.title: The Cost of Ego
docs.text:
If you prioritize winning over learning:

  • You'll claim wins you didn't earn → false confidence, no real improvement
  • You'll avoid situations where you might "lose" → you stop challenging yourself
  • You'll game the rules instead of developing skills → technique without understanding
  • You'll plateau because you're optimizing for the wrong thing

The athletes who improve fastest are the ones who are honest about what they can and can't do, who seek out challenges, and who treat every rep as an opportunity to learn something.

docs.title: In Skill Isolation Games
docs.text:
The win condition exists to give you a clear target. When you successfully parry, slip, or evade — that's feedback that you're understanding the skill. When you get hit, that's feedback that something needs work.

Don't rush to claim wins. Take the time to do it right. A clean success you can learn from is worth more than ten sloppy "wins" that teach you nothing.

docs.title: In Honor System Games
docs.text:
Some games (like Land the Target) rely on the attacker claiming when they've accomplished their goal. This only works if you're honest.

If you set out to land a left hook to the body and you land it cleanly, claim it. If you were actually going for the head and got lucky with a body shot, don't claim it — that's not what the game is training.

docs.title: In All Games
docs.text:
• Reset when you should reset
  • Don't bend the rules to avoid switching roles
  • Give your partner real resistance, not token opposition
  • Accept feedback (getting hit, getting taken down) as information, not failure

docs.title: For Coaches
docs.text:
Watch for athletes who: - Claim wins too quickly or frequently - Avoid being in the "losing" position - Get frustrated when the game exposes weaknesses - Prioritize looking good over getting better

These are signs of ego interfering with learning. Address the mindset directly:

"The goal isn't to win. The goal is to learn. If you're winning every time, we need to make it harder. If you're struggling, that's where the growth happens."

Create a training culture where struggle is valued, honesty is expected, and improvement matters more than performance.

docs.title: Summary
docs.text:
Games are academic exercises. Treat them that way.

Be your harshest critic. Only claim what you earned.

Prioritize learning over winning. Points are feedback, not trophies.

Your partner is your collaborator. You're both here to improve.

The athletes who adopt this mindset improve faster, develop deeper understanding, and ultimately become better fighters — because they're training for real skill, not imaginary points.

This principle applies across all games and may be referenced in game-specific documentation.

docs.title: Why "Leg Reclaim" instead of "Guard Recovery"?
docs.text:
Decision: Rename Guard Recovery to Leg Reclaim

docs.title: Why add Transition Zone?
docs.text:
Decision: Create a new environment between Striking and Wrestling

Rationale: - Clinch Denial and Boundary Trigger exist at the seam between domains - Counter-Striking and Counter-Wrestling are defensive responses to pressure - Visual clarity: shows the critical moment when striking becomes wrestling - Games in this zone handle domain transitions specifically

docs.title: Why are Counter-Striking and Counter-Wrestling defensive?
docs.text:
Decision: Classify counters as defensive focus

Rationale: - Counters respond to opponent initiation (reactive, not proactive) - The goal is deterrence: making initiation dangerous - You cannot counter without opponent action - Offense that serves defensive purpose

docs.title: FAQ & Troubleshooting
docs.text: Common questions and solutions for coaches using this system.

docs.title: What is the ecological approach?
docs.text:
The ecological approach to motor learning emphasizes:

  • Constraints-led training — Use rules and boundaries to shape behavior
  • Representative design — Training should mirror the demands of competition
  • Emergence — Skills emerge from practice, not just instruction
  • Exploration — Athletes discover solutions through guided play

Games in this system are designed to create learning conditions, not prescribe techniques.

docs.title: How is this different from traditional drilling?
docs.text: Traditional Drilling Ecological Games Coach prescribes technique Athlete discovers solutions Repetition of fixed movements Exploration of possibilities Compliance-focused Problem-solving focused Isolated from context Representative of real fighting

docs.title: Do I need to teach technique separately?
docs.text:
Technique instruction can complement games, but:

  • Games should come first — they create the "why"
  • Technique emerges from game play
  • Explicit instruction fills gaps, doesn't replace discovery
  • Over-coaching can reduce learning

docs.title: What is Full MMA Expression?
docs.text:
Full MMA Expression is the highest level of any game where cross-domain threats are added while maintaining the game's core focus:

  • Striking games add grappling threats (shoot, clinch)
  • Wrestling games add striking threats

See: Full MMA Expression Concept

docs.title: When should athletes attempt Full MMA Expression levels?
docs.text:
Only after they're proficient at lower levels. Signs of readiness:

  • Consistent success at levels 1-4
  • Primary skill feels automatic
  • Ready for additional cognitive load
  • Seeking realistic pressure

Don't rush it. The skill must be solid before adding complications.

docs.title: How do I scale Full MMA Expression appropriately?
docs.text:
Start conservative:

  1. Introduce the threat at low intensity
  2. Announce the threat before it happens ("I'm going to add a clinch option now")
  3. Gradually increase threat realism
  4. Pull back if athlete regresses on primary skill

docs.title: Do all games need Full MMA Expression?
docs.text:
Every game has a Full MMA Expression level documented, but not every session needs it. Most training happens at levels 1-4. Use Full MMA Expression when:

  • Athletes are proficient at lower levels
  • You want to stress-test skills
  • Preparing for competition

docs.title: "Athletes aren't switching roles in asymmetric games"
docs.text:
Problem: One side is dominating; roles aren't switching.

Solutions:

  1. Check skill levels — Mismatch may require intensity adjustment
  2. Review constraints — Are invariants being followed?
  3. Adjust levels — Drop to an easier level
  4. Add constraints — Give the struggling side an advantage (e.g., attacker must pause between strikes)

docs.title: "Athletes are gaming the rules instead of developing skills"
docs.text:
Problem: Athletes find loopholes that win the game without developing the target skill.

Solutions:

  1. Address mindset — Reference the Training Mindset principle
  2. Close the loophole — Add or clarify invariants
  3. Adjust the level — The current level may be too easy or too hard
  4. Discuss with athlete — They may not realize what they're doing

docs.title: "Athletes get frustrated when they can't 'win'"
docs.text:
Problem: Competitive mindset interfering with learning.

Solutions:

  1. Reframe success — Success is learning, not winning
  2. Remove scorekeeping — Some games work better without tracking
  3. Emphasize process — Celebrate good attempts, not just results
  4. Reference principles — The Training Mindset addresses this directly

docs.title: "Games feel chaotic or unstructured"
docs.text:
Problem: Athletes don't know what they're supposed to be doing.

Solutions:

  1. Clarify objectives — Ensure everyone knows the goal
  2. Demonstrate — Show what good play looks like
  3. Start simpler — Drop to Level 1
  4. Check prerequisites — Athletes may lack foundational skills

docs.title: How hard should contact be?
docs.text:
The system uses these contact levels:

Level Description When to Use Touch Contact made but no force Skill isolation, beginners Light Force felt but not damaging Most development games Moderate Significant force, controlled Advanced games, integration

When in doubt, go lighter. Quality over intensity.

docs.title: When should I stop a game?
docs.text:
Stop immediately if:

  • An athlete loses composure
  • Contact becomes excessive
  • Rules are being ignored
  • An athlete appears hurt
  • The learning environment breaks down

Reset, address the issue, then resume.

docs.title: How do I manage aggression?
docs.text:
Some athletes escalate intensity inappropriately:

  1. Set expectations clearly — Before the game starts
  2. Match intensity — Pair athletes of similar intensity preference
  3. Call resets — Interrupt escalation early
  4. Address privately — Discuss mindset after the session
  5. Adjust pairing — Some athletes shouldn't work together

docs.title: How long should rounds be?
docs.text:
Suggested round lengths:

Game Type Round Length Skill isolation 2-4 minutes Development games 4-6 minutes Combined games 3-5 minutes Integration 5-10 minutes

Shorter rounds with more resets often work better than long continuous play.

docs.title: How many games per session?
docs.text:
Quality over quantity:

  • Beginners: 2-3 games, more time per game
  • Intermediate: 3-4 games, balanced time
  • Advanced: Can handle more variety

One well-developed skill beats five superficial exposures.

docs.title: What if I don't have the right equipment?
docs.text:
Adapt as needed:

Ideal Equipment Adaptation Wall/cage Marked boundary, padded wall, corner Mats Grass, carpet, reduced ground work Gloves Lighter contact, open-hand games Boundary markers Tape, cones, imaginary lines

The constraints matter more than the equipment.

docs.title: How do I know if I'm improving?
docs.text:
Look for:

  • Consistency — Can you repeat successful actions?
  • Variety — Do you have multiple solutions?
  • Composure — Are you calmer under pressure?
  • Recognition — Do you see opportunities earlier?
  • Transfer — Does skill show up in sparring?

docs.title: What if I keep losing at a game?
docs.text:
Losing is learning:

  1. Analyze — What specifically is going wrong?
  2. Ask — Get feedback from partner or coach
  3. Simplify — Drop to an easier level
  4. Focus — Work on one thing at a time
  5. Persist — Struggle is where growth happens

Reference: Training Mindset principle

docs.title: Should I always play to win?
docs.text:
No. Games are academic exercises:

  • Learning matters more than winning
  • Honest play creates real feedback
  • Struggle is valuable
  • Your partner is your collaborator

See: Training Mindset principle

docs.title: Glossary
docs.text: Key terminology used throughout the Ecological MMA Games System.

docs.title: Pin
docs.text: A control position where the defender's movement options are significantly limited by the attacker's body position and pressure. Distinct from TKO Pin.

docs.title: Top Control
docs.text: Controlling position on the ground where the attacker is above the defender, managing hips and shoulders.

docs.title: TKO Pin
docs.text:
A control state (not just a position) where:

  • Hips and shoulders are meaningfully controlled
  • Posture and mobility are compromised
  • At least one limb is free to strike effectively
  • Defender options are high-cost

See: TKO Pin Concept

docs.title: Scramble
docs.text:
A transition state where control is contested. Neither athlete has established position. Outcome depends on:

  • Hip mobility
  • Base recovery
  • Positional awareness

docs.title: Disengagement
docs.text: Successfully breaking contact and returning to a neutral position with defensive posture established.

docs.title: Access
docs.text: The ability to connect or engage with an opponent. First phase of any exchange.

docs.title: Stabilize
docs.text: Preventing escape or reversal after connection is made. Control establishment phase.

docs.title: Exploit
docs.text: Executing damage (strikes), submissions, or positional advancement from a stable position.

docs.title: Counter
docs.text: Interrupting, escaping, or reversing the opponent's attack. Defensive response phase.

docs.title: Defensive Neck Submissions (DNS)
docs.text:
Neck attacks (guillotines, front headlocks) used defensively to punish:

  • Poor posture
  • Over-committed control attempts
  • Head position errors

DNS is allowed in most grappling games as a defensive tool, not as a primary objective.

docs.title: Full MMA Expression
docs.text:
The highest level of any game where cross-domain threats are added while maintaining the game's core focus:

  • Striking games add grappling threats (shoot, clinch)
  • Wrestling games add striking threats

This ensures skills are tested under realistic MMA pressure without overwhelming beginners with complexity.

See: Full MMA Expression Concept

docs.title: Representative Design
docs.text: Training that mimics the decision-making context of competition. The environment creates the learning, not verbal instruction.

docs.title: Invariants
docs.text:
Fixed rules within a game that cannot be violated. They define the problem space and constrain behavior.

Example: "No clinching in open space" (Winning the Circle)

docs.title: Task Focus
docs.text: The specific perceptual and motor challenges an athlete must solve within a game.

docs.title: Constraints
docs.text: Environmental, task, or rule limitations that shape behavior. In ecological training, constraints replace instructions.

docs.title: Open Space
docs.text: Training area without structural constraints (walls, cages). Movement is unrestricted.

docs.title: Boundary
docs.text: Edge of the training area (wall, cage, marked line) that limits retreat and triggers new behaviors.

docs.title: Wall Environment
docs.text: Training context where the wall/cage is the dominant constraint. Changes available techniques and strategies.

docs.title: Ground Environment
docs.text: Training context where both athletes are on the ground. Gravity and horizontal positioning become dominant.

docs.title: Game
docs.text:
A distinct learning problem with:

  • Stable environment
  • Clear goal
  • Defined invariants
  • Clear win conditions

docs.title: Level
docs.text:
A progression inside the same game:

  • Same environment
  • Same core problem
  • Stricter or more complete success criteria

See: Levels vs Games

docs.title: Entry Condition
docs.text: The starting setup for a game — positions, distances, and reset rules.

docs.title: Win Condition
docs.text: How success is determined for each role in a game.

docs.title: Informational Strikes
docs.text: Light contact strikes used to measure distance, create reactions, or test control — not intended to cause damage.

docs.title: Controlled Descent
docs.text: Bringing an opponent to the ground while maintaining connection and balance. Opposite of "dumping."

docs.title: Dumping
docs.text: Using bodyweight or momentum to force an opponent down without proper control. Unsafe and penalized.

docs.title: System Overview
docs.text: The Ecological MMA Games System is a decision-state framework for organizing MMA training around problems, not techniques.

docs.title: Core Premise
docs.text:
MMA interactions repeat predictable decision patterns:

  • Accessing an opponent
  • Stabilizing position
  • Exploiting with strikes or submissions
  • Countering escapes or reversals

The system is designed around these decision states, not named techniques.

docs.title: The Universal Pattern

    B --> C[EXPLOIT]

    style C fill:#FF5722,color:#fff

Establishing pin, controlling hips Exploit Can I strike, submit, or advance? TKO pin, ground and pound Counter Can the opponent interrupt or escape? Escape, reversal, DNS

docs.title: Environmental Layers
docs.text:
The dominant environment matters more than technique:

Environment Characteristics Open Space No structural constraints, movement dominant Wall Vertical constraint, limits retreat Ground Horizontal constraint, gravity dominant

Environment Determines Game

When the dominant environment changes, the learning problem usually changes. This is the primary factor for deciding when to create a new game versus a new level.

docs.title: 1. The Environment Does the Teaching
docs.text:
We use Representative Design:

  • Behavior should emerge from constraints
  • Athletes learn by solving problems, not following instructions
  • The coach designs the environment, not the solution

docs.title: 2. Control Precedes Damage
docs.text:
Across all environments:

  • Control comes before striking
  • Stability comes before exploitation

Strikes are allowed in most games, but they are informational and carry positional trade-offs.

docs.title: 3. Every Offense Needs a Defense
docs.text:
The system is built symmetrically:

  • If we teach pinning, we must teach escaping
  • If we teach takedowns, we must teach scrambles
  • No domination layer exists without a corresponding resistance layer

docs.title: System Integrity Checks
docs.text:
Red Flags

If you observe these patterns, the constraints are mis-set, not the athlete.

Red Flag Likely Cause Brute force domination Skill mismatch or intensity too high Memorized repetitions Game is too predictable Ego escalation Competitive framing instead of learning Confusion about goals Win conditions unclear No defensive success Constraints favor offense too heavily

docs.title: Diagnosis Protocol
docs.text:
When red flags appear:

  1. Stop the game
  2. Review constraints and invariants
  3. Check intensity levels
  4. Clarify win conditions
  5. Adjust and restart

docs.title: Session Structure Guidelines
docs.text:
A well-designed session follows this pattern:

1. Warm-up game (simpler, lower intensity)        — 8-10 min
2. Skill builder #1 (isolated skill)              — 10-12 min
3. Skill builder #2 (related skill or progression) — 10-12 min
4. Integration game (combine skills)              — 12-15 min
5. Live application (combined or free play)       — 15-20 min

docs.title: Safety & Intensity Rules
docs.text:
Non-Negotiable

Safety principles in this system are non-negotiable. They cannot be overridden for competitive pressure, athlete preference, or training efficiency.

docs.title: 1. No Falling Bodyweight onto Legs
docs.text: Takedowns and transitions must never involve dropping bodyweight onto an opponent's legs or knees.

docs.title: 2. Control Precedes Gravity
docs.text: All takedowns are created via off-balancing, not dumping. The opponent's base must be compromised before descent begins.

docs.title: 3. Strikes are Informational
docs.text: Strikes in training games are light and informational. They measure distance, create reactions, and test control — not cause damage.

docs.title: 4. Submissions are Emergent
docs.text:
FLAGGED FOR REVIEW

This section contains errors and needs revision. Content below is placeholder until corrected.

Submissions (especially DNS) are defensive tools that emerge from constraints. No jumping guard, no sitting to finish, no hunting submissions as primary objectives.

docs.title: 5. Coach Intervention is Mandatory
docs.text:
The coach must stop play immediately when:

  • Structure degrades into scrambling chaos
  • Intensity escalates beyond appropriate levels
  • Any safety violation occurs
  • Learning value has disappeared

docs.title: Intensity Guidelines
docs.text:
Athlete Level Recommended Intensity Notes Beginner 30–40% Focus on pattern recognition Intermediate 40–60% Add resistance and timing pressure Advanced 60–75% Realistic problem-solving Maximum Cap 80% Never exceed in training games

80% Cap

Even advanced athletes should not exceed 80% intensity in ecological games. These are learning environments, not competition simulations.

docs.title: Red Flags (Stop Immediately)
docs.text:
Red Flag Indicates Brute force without technique Constraints are mis-set Memorized repetitions without adaptation Game is too predictable Ego-driven intensity escalation Competitive mindset has taken over Panic responses Athlete is overwhelmed Static grinding without progress No learning is occurring

When red flags appear, stop the game and reassess:

  • Are constraints appropriate?
  • Is intensity appropriate?
  • Does the athlete understand the problem?

docs.title: Open Space
docs.text:
• No chasing collisions
  • No forward crashes
  • Reset if exchanges become static

docs.title: Wall

FLAGGED FOR REVIEW

  • No grinding into wall
  • No neck cranks
  • Light strikes only

docs.title: Transitions (Wall → Ground)
docs.text:
• Control precedes gravity (critical)
  • No dumping bodyweight
  • No slamming
  • Stop if descent becomes uncontrolled

docs.title: Ground
docs.text:

  • DNS recognized and stopped before completion
  • No sustained suffocation

docs.title: DNS in Training
docs.text:
Defensive Neck Submissions (guillotines, front headlocks) occur when the attacker's head drops into a vulnerable position. The defender can capitalize on this with a choke.

DNS is not a safety concern — it's a natural consequence of poor head position.

  • If playing to submission: DNS goes to finish
  • If DNS leads to ground with submission maintained: continue to finish
  • Standard tap rules apply as with any submission

docs.title: Intervention Language
docs.text:
Coaches should use clear, consistent language:

Command Meaning "Reset" Return to starting position "Freeze" Stop all movement immediately "Check intensity" Reduce effort level "Time" Round complete "Out" Exit the game (safety concern)

docs.title: Athlete Responsibility
docs.text:
Athletes are expected to:

  • Respect tap signals immediately
  • Self-regulate intensity
  • Report any discomfort or injury
  • Prioritize partner safety over "winning"

Culture of Safety

The safest gyms are those where athletes actively protect each other, not just themselves.

System Evolution Notice

Safety rules may be expanded as new games or contexts are added.

docs.title: Session Planning Guide
docs.text: This guide provides considerations for coaches planning training sessions. Sessions are game-based from start to finish — there is no prescribed structure.

docs.title: Core Philosophy
docs.text:
No Universal Session Template

Session structure is entirely dependent on the training goal. What you work on depends on:

  • The specific skill or problem being addressed
  • The athletes present and their current development
  • Whether this is general training or fight-specific preparation
  • Time available and equipment constraints

There is no "typical session" pattern to follow.

docs.title: Warm-Up Expectations
docs.text:
Athletes should arrive ready to play.

The expectation is that athletes warm up before class begins. Games start immediately — they are the training, not something that happens after warm-up.

Coach Awareness

A coach may be aware that athletes haven't warmed up and can:

  • Start the first game at lower intensity
  • Choose a less physically demanding game to begin
  • Allow athletes to ease into full engagement

This is situational judgment, not a default session structure. The system doesn't prescribe "warm-up games" as a phase.

docs.title: 1. Goal-Driven Selection
docs.text:
Every session should have a clear training objective:

  • What problem are we solving today?
  • What skill are we developing?
  • What does success look like?

Select games that address that objective. Don't run games just to fill time.

docs.title: 2. Prerequisite Awareness
docs.text:
Before running a game, ensure athletes have experience with its prerequisites:

  • Check the game's frontmatter for prerequisite concepts and games
  • If athletes lack prerequisites, address those first
  • Simpler games prepare athletes for complex ones

docs.title: 3. Role Balance
docs.text:
In asymmetric games, ensure athletes experience both sides:

  • Switch roles regularly
  • Track total time in each role
  • Some athletes may need more time in specific roles based on their development needs

docs.title: 4. Intensity Management
docs.text:
Match game intensity to session goals and athlete readiness:

  • High intensity: Shorter rounds, more rest between
  • Skill development: Moderate intensity, focus on quality over volume
  • Technical work: Lower intensity, more repetitions and feedback

docs.title: Common Mistakes
docs.text:
Avoid These Pitfalls

  • Too much variety — Better to develop one skill deeply than touch many superficially
  • Skipping prerequisites — Complex games fail without foundational skills
  • Unbalanced roles — Athletes need time on both sides of asymmetric games
  • Ignoring fatigue — Quality degrades when athletes are exhausted; adjust or end the session
  • Rigid adherence to a plan — If something isn't working, adapt

docs.title: General Class vs. Fight Camp
docs.text: Context Considerations General class Broader skill development, more variety across sessions Fight camp Focused on specific problems the athlete needs to solve

docs.title: Athlete Level
docs.text: Level Considerations Beginners Simpler games, more instruction, build vocabulary Intermediate Progress through game levels, introduce combined games Advanced Nuanced work, game modifications, more autonomy

docs.title: Time Available
docs.text: Time Considerations Short session Focus on one game, work through levels Long session Can address related skills, more games in sequence

docs.title: Using Game Metadata
docs.text:
Each game's frontmatter includes useful planning information:

  • Prerequisites — What must athletes already know?
  • Difficulty — Is this appropriate for the group?
  • Duration — How long are typical rounds?
  • Equipment — What do we need?

Use this metadata to make informed game selections.

Development Notice

This guide may be refined based on coaching feedback and experience.

docs.title: WIN CONDITIONS
docs.text:
Clear, observable criteria for success for each side. Avoid vague conditions.

"A Side wins by controlling B Side"

Good Win Condition

"A Side (Attacker) wins by holding functional pin (flat shoulders, controlled hips) for 5 seconds"

Gamification

Win conditions encourage engagement. Even skill isolation games benefit from clear win conditions with role switching (see Confidence Rating concept — successful defense = role switch).
